security_audit.summary: Official Anthropic skill for creating Claude Code plugin skills. Contains documentation and best practices only, with references to scripts (init_skill.py, package_skill.py) that are not included in this skill package. No executable code or dangerous patterns present.

content.user_title: Skill Development Guide for Claude Code Plugins
content.value_statement: This skill teaches you how to create effective, well-structured skills for Claude Code plugins using progressive disclosure patterns, proper triggering, and best practices for organizing documentation, examples, and scripts.
actual_capabilities: Guide users through the complete 6-step skill creation process
Explain progressive disclosure (metadata, SKILL.md, bundled resources)
Teach proper SKILL.md frontmatter structure with trigger phrases
Show how to organize scripts/, references/, and examples/ directories
Demonstrate imperative/infinitive writing style for AI consumption
Provide validation checklist for skill quality
Offer complete examples from plugin-dev skills
Show common mistakes and anti-patterns to avoid
limitations: Does not include the init_skill.py or package_skill.py scripts mentioned in references
Focused on Claude Code plugin skills, not standalone skill packages
Does not automatically validate or test created skills
Requires manual implementation of skill structure and content

use_cases.title: Create a New Plugin Skill
use_cases.description: Walk through the complete process of creating a new skill for a Claude Code plugin, from understanding use cases to implementing SKILL.md with proper structure and trigger phrases.
use_cases.target_user: Plugin developers adding new capabilities to their Claude Code plugins

use_cases.title: Improve Existing Skill Descriptions
use_cases.description: Refactor skill descriptions to use third-person format with specific trigger phrases, ensuring skills load at the right time.

use_cases.title: Organize Skill Content with Progressive Disclosure
use_cases.description: Restructure bloated SKILL.md files by moving detailed content to references/, keeping core instructions lean while maintaining comprehensive documentation.
use_cases.target_user: Developers with existing skills that need better organization

use_cases.title: Validate Skill Quality
use_cases.description: Use the comprehensive validation checklist to ensure skills follow best practices for structure, writing style, and progressive disclosure.
use_cases.target_user: Quality-focused plugin developers preparing skills for release

prompt_templates.title: Create a New Skill
prompt_templates.prompt: I want to create a skill for [domain/task]. Users will ask things like "[example user query 1]" and "[example user query 2]". Help me design and implement this skill.
prompt_templates.scenario: Starting a new skill from scratch with clear use cases

prompt_templates.title: Improve Skill Description
prompt_templates.prompt: My skill description is "[current description]". Help me rewrite it with specific trigger phrases in third-person format.
prompt_templates.scenario: Refactoring existing skill to improve triggering

prompt_templates.title: Organize Large SKILL.md
prompt_templates.prompt: My SKILL.md is [X] words long and has sections on [topics]. Help me split this into SKILL.md + references/ using progressive disclosure.
prompt_templates.scenario: Refactoring bloated skill file into lean structure

prompt_templates.title: Validate Skill Before Release
prompt_templates.prompt: Review my skill at [path] and check if it follows best practices for description, writing style, and organization.
prompt_templates.scenario: Quality check before publishing a skill

output_examples.input: Help me create a skill for managing database migrations in my project
output_examples.output: Creates skill structure with: (1) SKILL.md with frontmatter using triggers like "create migration", "run database migration", "rollback migration"; (2) references/migration-patterns.md for detailed procedures; (3) examples/migration-template.sql; (4) scripts/validate-migration.sh utility

output_examples.input: My skill description says 'Use this skill when you need help with hooks'
output_examples.output: Refactors to: 'This skill should be used when the user asks to "create a hook", "add a PreToolUse hook", "validate tool use", "implement prompt-based hooks", or mentions hook events (PreToolUse, PostToolUse, Stop).'

best_practices: Use third-person format in description: "This skill should be used when..."
Include specific trigger phrases users would actually say
Keep SKILL.md body lean (1,500-2,000 words ideal, under 3,000 max)
Move detailed content to references/ for progressive disclosure
Write entire skill in imperative/infinitive form, not second person
Reference all supporting files clearly in SKILL.md
Create only directories you actually need (references/, examples/, scripts/)
Study plugin-dev skills as templates for best practices
Use validation checklist before finalizing skill
Test skills by triggering with expected user queries
anti_patterns: Vague descriptions without specific trigger phrases
Using second person ("You should...") instead of imperative form
Putting everything in SKILL.md without using progressive disclosure
Not referencing bundled resources from SKILL.md
Creating example directories without actually needing them
Writing descriptions in first person or command form
Duplicating content between SKILL.md and references/
Missing frontmatter or required fields (name, description)
Using generic triggers like "when user needs help with X"

faq.question: What's the difference between scripts/, references/, and assets/?
faq.answer: scripts/ contains executable code for deterministic tasks; references/ contains documentation loaded as needed into context; assets/ contains files used in output (templates, images) that aren't loaded into context.

faq.question: How do I know if my SKILL.md is too long?
faq.answer: Target 1,500-2,000 words for the body. If over 3,000 words, move detailed content to references/. Core concepts stay in SKILL.md, detailed patterns and advanced techniques go to references/.

faq.question: What makes a good skill description for triggering?
faq.answer: Use third person ("This skill should be used when..."), include specific phrases users would say ("create a hook", "validate tool use"), and list concrete scenarios. Avoid vague descriptions like "Provides hook guidance."

faq.question: Do plugin skills need to be packaged as ZIP files?
faq.answer: No. Plugin skills are distributed as part of the plugin, not as separate packages. Users get skills automatically when they install the plugin.

faq.question: How does progressive disclosure work?
faq.answer: Three levels: (1) Metadata (name+description) always in context; (2) SKILL.md body loaded when skill triggers; (3) Bundled resources (references/examples/scripts) loaded as needed by Claude.

faq.question: Should I use init_skill.py for plugin skills?
faq.answer: No. The init_skill.py script is for generic standalone skills. Plugin skills are created manually in the plugin's skills/ directory with a simpler structure.
